name: nytimes
text:
We asked experts: If you could do one thing right now to help fix America — no matter how large or small — what would it be?

You may agree or disagree with the ideas that follow but, at a minimum, hopefully they’ll make you think about what is possible. https://t.co/n89gKn56W8

name: nytimes
text: As a year of disruption closes, those with scrapped travel plans grapple with a sense of loss about places not seen, experiences not had, people not hugged and time that’s impossible to get back. https://t.co/3IaPliDbje

name: nytimes
text: Thousands ill. Hundreds dying. Lives forever altered. As virus cases soar around the U.S., we take an in-depth look at the nation’s first epicenter of the pandemic. Our 16-page special section was published in Sunday's paper. Read it online here: https://t.co/r3UGzZ20Ib https://t.co/tWQeUqpzd7

name: nytimes

text:
In Opinion

name: nytimes
text:
Survivor’s guilt, anger, second thoughts and nightmares. 

These are just some of the things that plague the minds and hearts of the people of Bergamo, Italy — one of the first places stricken with the coronavirus. https://t.co/iOUS0GFTDj

name: nytimes
text: Bergamo gave the West its first look at the horrors to come — oxygen-starved grandparents, overflowing hospitals and a parade of coffins. Now, it hangs suspended in what feels like a post-apocalyptic aftermath. https://t.co/TdrOnroCav https://t.co/IifhwFXwA9

name: nytimes
text: The people fear that Bergamo’s enormous sacrifice will fade into history, but more than that, there is a collective grappling to understand how the virus has changed them. https://t.co/TdrOnroCav https://t.co/0vJkh8R6zd

name: nytimes
text: In the town of Osio Sopra, Sara Cagliani, 30, can’t move past her failure to fulfill her father’s dying wish: to be buried in his Alpine soldier’s uniform. Morticians told her dressing bodies was too risky. https://t.co/TdrOnroCav https://t.co/TkPfmrsjxH

name: nytimes
text:
Others are haunted by the choices the virus forced them to make. 

Laura Soliveri couldn’t choose who should get the scant supplemental oxygen she could find: her mother, or her husband. He died, age 64, in April. Her mother, 85, survived. https://t.co/TdrOnroCav

name: nytimes
text: Many are enlisting the help of mental health professionals. Others are taking a self-destructive route. Doctors in Bergamo have reported a spike in anxiety, depression and substance abuse. https://t.co/TdrOnroCav https://t.co/NwjXydO3j1

name: nytimes
text:
Doctors and nurses in Bergamo, once heralded as heroes, are now the target of vitriol over cancelled appointments.

“It’s not like it used to be. There’s a lot of anger," said Katia Marcassoli, a nurse at Pesenti Fenaroli hospital. https://t.co/TdrOnroCav https://t.co/BMJxjkSFIe

name: nytimes
text:
The scars the coronavirus left on the residents of Bergamo are unseen and incalculable. 

Read the full story by @jasondhorowitz, with photos by Fabio Bucciarelli: https://t.co/TdrOnroCav https://t.co/Cd10iaPA4Z

name: nytimes
text: 🎧 Trees appear to be communicating through underground networks of fungi. What exactly are they sharing with one another? Listen to the narrated story by @ferrisjabr on The Sunday Read. https://t.co/etDtrZnf0f
